heisig_chinese_memo: The chinese inch is an old Chinese measurement equal to a bit less that 1.33 English inches.  Since this is about a tenth of a foot we can say it's one drop of ten.
heisig_constituent: measurement, glue, drop, ten with a hook
heisig_story: This kanji actually stood for a small measurement used prior to the metric system, a bit over an inch in length, and from there acquired the sense of measurement. In the old system, it was one-tenth of a shaku (whose kanji we shall meet in frame 1151). The picture, appropriately, represents one drop of a ten (with a hook!).
koohiiStory1: The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.
koohiiStory2: Glue two sticks together to make the best measurement. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (ã™ã‚“).
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

origin_of_ch_char_book: (å°Š, zun, respect) At the top of the character, there is a cup of wine, and below is the hand holding the cup with the fingers bent (å¯¸, cun=tsâ€™un, unit of length, approximately 3cm). It shows that one gives wine to the honorable spirits of the ancestors or gods. Nowadays, this character means â€˜respectâ€™.,The Shang Dynasty was established in a location far away from the sea, so it was difficult to get seashells. Yet very beautiful round seashells are found in the Shang Dynasty tombs. Such precious shells were used as currency. In Hanzi=tzu, many words and symbols refer to seashells. Several words are related to the seashell. For example, (å¾—, de, get) shows hand bending a finger (å¯¸, cun=tsâ€™un, a small unit of length) to pick up a seashell (è´, bei, shellfish, the original type is) on the road. (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, walk). It literally means â€œwalking down to the road and picking up a seashell by chanceâ€.
humanum_full_description_en:
"Shuowen": "Cun, ten years. But the hand moves every inch, which is called Cunkou. From again, from one."

Click " inch " word not found in inscriptions alone, but as a Bronze parts, and more with " and " universal, meaning hand. For example, the character of " Zun " of Jiu Zun is from "å»¾" ("å»¾" is from two and "you", that is, two hands), " Suowen " or the body is from " inch ", "å»¾" and " inch " both indicate hand shape. See also " Zun ", " Pay ", " Temple ". The " inch " of Qin bamboo slips and Mawangdui Han silk script is used as a measurement unit. In addition, "Mawangdui. Health side ", the" turn "to the next draw plus" and "above, we can see" inch "refers to the original meaning if" Exists ", whether that thing word is still room for discussion. The original meaning is probably a hand, and the next stroke of " again " may be a pen.
humanum_short_description_en: Lin Yiguang: ""It's like a hand again; "One" is one inch behind the hand." Scholars believe that " inch " is a word that matter, " and " shaped like a hand, " a " to mean something symbolic, just as indicated at the Cunkou that Chinese medicine Qiemo at high wrist bone located below.

Heisig constituents: measurement, glue, drop, ten with a hook
Heisig: This kanji actually stood for a small measurement used prior to the metric system, a bit over an inch in length, and from there acquired the sense of measurement. In the old system, it was one-tenth of a shaku (whose kanji we shall meet in frame 1151). The picture, appropriately, represents one drop of a ten (with a hook!).
* As a primitive, we shall use this to mean glue or glued to. There is no need to devise a story to remember this, since the primitive will appear so often you would have to struggle hard NOT to remember it.
Chinese: The chinese inch is an old Chinese measurement equal to a bit less that 1.33 English inches. Since this is about a tenth of a foot we can say it's one drop of ten.
koohii1: The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.
koohii2: Glue two sticks together to make the best measurement. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).

Radicals: å¯¸  (measurement)
Meaning Mnemonic
The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same.
If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
Reading Mnemonic
You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (ã™ã‚“).
Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.
